title: Balance and Compromise: Issues in Content Localization
segmentation: Alright hi my name is Lee Janadi.
I spent 10 years as a copywriter, 10 years managing web properties for large multinational Corporation for the last 18 months.
I've been an independent content strategy and I'm here today not to talk about technology at all.

In fact, I'm here to talk to you today about the need for having a content strategy up front for a source language weaving localization issues into that source left into that content strategy up front.
And how that can possibly help some of the issues that we are addressing in the localization.
So localization on the web.
Seen as by many as being very costly, very time consuming.
It takes a long time to get it translated content back into publishing.
Circuit quality seems to be an ongoing issue.
Budgets are fragmented between web content and assets between certain sets.
Sections of the site and others.
It requires a lot of supporting tools and processes and it creates a lot of complexity and information architecture in search engine optimization and look and feel.
In your content management systems.
And it's all made all that much more complex when there is a lack of content strategy at the source.
So content in general there's a very lack of governance of content.
It's seen as a cost.
ROI is not measured, and we are having difficulty measuring the value that content actually brings.
Because we haven't really set objectives for what we want to accomplish.
So content strategy for the web is an emerging practice that is being is being proposed by a lot of people.

Notably Christina Halvorson, who is an author and content strategy of content strategy for the web, and her definition is content strategy plans for the creation, delivery, and governance of useful, usable.
Content.

Useful serves a purpose.
We know why the content is there, it's user centered, so you know addresses a user requirement.

It's concise, you know it does have spent hours looking forward, and it's supported by tools by people.

There's a real process involved to having a strategic approach to content, and it starts by setting objectives OK. What do you want?

Why are you doing this?
It helps to have a handle on what you have.
Many people have no idea what content they have out there.

What even tools are in the system.
Once you have some idea of that, you can then start identifying pain points, low hanging fruit to identify well, what can we leverage?
What do we need to optimize?
Develop a plan, a strategic plan, why, who, when, and then tactical plans.
You know, editorial calendars, page specifications.
The details at every level of the site, what you should be doing and what kind of messaging you should have and then carrying out the plan.
Obviously maintaining and measuring it refreshed, refine and continue.
It's a process, not a project.
And you should have a sustainable content strategy.
So.

Well, when it's appropriate, it applies to the local context you are talking about.
Products that are being sold in that particular country or locale.
It's useful, addresses a specific market specific purpose.
If you are established in one country but just starting out, another is unlikely that you were going to have the same purpose for your content.
It's user centered, so obviously language plays a very key poor role in having user centered content.
It's clear your translation quality is hard, it's been localized.
If it needs to be localized, it's consistent.
The terminology is used consistently, which not only reinforces brain requirements but also.
Will help maintain translation costs down thanks to more exact matches and less fuzzy matches.
An it's concise.
You know we have saying less is more.

So one of the things that we can do is write asking right from the start.

When we started setting objectives for, start asking the right questions you know, taking into account all these localizations, the market forces you know, the market sizes, potentials of certain markets, legal and contractual obligations, not of the country, not just only at the country but also partners that you may be working.
Your brand recognition.
Are you selling something that you know or do people know you?
Or do they even know what you're talking about?
And what's your competition doing?
Are you playing catch up or is this something that you could distinguish yourself out?

Of course, your internal forces you know you're not going to have the same presence for a market where you have 3000 people in a very entrenched presence and or at a market where you have two people trying to set things up, going the consistency of your offering.
How are you selling the whole product set apart of the product?
Set the full product set, but it's been localized itself.
Those things need to be addressed, but they also need to be balanced against cultural.
Horses ability to use, you know, to speak English?
OK language preferences.
And for audiences, your various audiences.
Not just OK.
This is Italy.
Well, no, you probably are addressing different types of audiences in Italy.
And so if you have to make choices, maybe that is something that you need to address.
It's unlikely that a CIO who goes to conferences worldwide has the same ability with with with English, for instance as an installation manager or something.
So if you have to make choices in which you're going to translate or not.
These are issues.
Is she looking at and then obviously just the site objectives itself?
What are you trying to accomplish with the site with the content on your site?
There are different objectives throughout the site and the deeper and more complex the relationship you want to have with your users.
The more you have to translate.

Do you have?

A little bit?
Look at the web pages and your content assets, because those are probably going to be handled in different ways.
How often does the content changes a stock content or flow content?
Is it stock that's going to stay for a year or is it flow content that changes every week every three months or?
You're going to need to manage a lot more carefully.
What is the relevance to the local audience?

The budget for this and then you also have to look at your governance model.
Do you have a centralized or decentralized language management system or process?
Is it in source?
Is it outsourced or is it a hybrid?

What about the web team?
What's their role with respect to manage translation?
Do they translate themselves?
Do they validate?
Do they get some SMB somewhere to validate?
What's the process for that?
And again, who owns them?
Tools tools are central to the whole process, So what is the tool set that is available if any?
I mean there are a lot of companies today that don't have the property sites and are not working in this consistent fashion with Dell's PC can help them their latency.
Try to get a handle on what is the latency in your various markets.
Are some markets consistently late to the game?
Is it taking four months in Italy where as it's taking in one month somewhere else or two weeks somewhere else?
What are you trying to get in?
Where are the issues and where the problems metrics?

So if you're spending a lot of time investing into localising your website and yet you know 80% of traffic is still going to the English default site, you have an issue you know sooner or later somebody's going to say, well, sorry, but this is not going to.
The budget is not really.
That is not going to follow.
You don't have enough traffic.

Viable and everybody's going to be inside anyways, so you have to address the problems that are created.
The this, this dysfunction map and what are the costs?
I mean, do people know what it's costing you?

You don't have to say yes, we translate no, we don't.
You can obviously translate everything as is, but then you can also chunk content is very common.
Things like product for instance where 90% of the content is the same for for every for every market.
But then you have to add 10% maybe to talk about certain compliance issues or regulatory issues.
But you can also change things.
I mean if you have a very large section of something, for instance, and you know you're not going to be able to translate it.
Well, maybe you can shorten it.

You can rethink it as well.

And of course you can make the decision to decide to leave it and just linked it to English and then you just basically have to write it in a way that it's not going to make people laugh when they do the machine translation.
And of course I'll inventory and local.

Need to rely on a whole lot of other people to help them identify what has been translated, what has been localized, how is maintained, and also look at what's out there as well, because this is 1 area where there's a lot of many sites, a lot of extra activity that just sort of falls into the Raider of every.
Of every.
And then you get into the specifics.
I mean, one of the things we talked about a little bit earlier.
When you get into your tactical planning, you get into editorial page specifications.
I mean, there should be at a specification before you write the content that is going to outline the objectives of that page.
What are the primary and secondary messages were trying to get across with that page?
What's the voice and tone we want to be using here?
What are the calls to action?
We want users to do when they get to the page images and call?
That's what we want on any terminology requirements that need to be.
And respected those should be on the editorial page specific.
But they also should address localization issues right from the start.
You know here.

Yes, no.
Do we chunk?
What do we change?
What gets global and what is local?
And if you can address these issues at the tier level, that would be best.
At the locality level you made, you want to go so you know so far is include well, So what are the keywords localized?
SCO keywords that you want to include here.

If you have a very informal tone in your source language, well, you might want to say OK. Well, here we need to take it up A notch for this particular market, because it's not as an informal market is as North America or any of the UK or angle phone markets.
Where is the source content going to come from if there are local differences and who's going to validate that local content interface?
So obviously getting it done and keeping it sent one of the things that one of the key messages really don't try to do it all at once.

You know, we really have to get out of managing websites as projects and making sure that it's an ongoing project, because somebody sees you know all of this, it's enough to send people running the other way.
Use tools obviously encourage web teams to look at what tools are available to them.
Work with language service providers in the much closer relationship than they have been.
Find alternatives to your latency issues, because otherwise you know you will have budget cuts for that.

Track your metrics, track your costs, and if all else you know if anything else you have a traffic manager who can help you manage the directions and make it their job, their responsibility to manage the interactions.

What I have to say?
